summary: Do you hate oberyn?
question: Do you hate oberyn?
answer:
No. He is one of my favorite characters but I have to be realistic about the darker turns of his nature given specific circumstances.

Ned Stark committed treason twice to save the lives of innocent children: his nephew and the Baratheon children. But given circumstances of Balon Greyjoy rebelling early and the king called for the head of Theon Greyjoy as retaliation, would Ned Stark use Ice to behead a boy he raised for a decade or betray Robert by sparing him?

Robb Stark wouldn’t.

His father is a coin flip.

Oberyn Martell would no more care for Jon Snow than Brynden Tully did, but that doesn’t mean he would murder a child on a whim (the Martells are not Tyrells, Lannisters, Arryns, or Baratheons).

But if someone was trying to use Jon Snow as a figurehead against Elia or Aegon? Another Blackfyre rebellion was looming on the horizon?

summary: Why is Val given so much importance by the Wildlings? Is it simply that she is the sister of their presumably dead king's wife...
question: Why is Val given so much importance by the Wildlings? Is it simply that she is the sister of their presumably dead king's wife who is nursing his son or is there more to her than meets the eye?
answer:
Val is not only Dalla’s sister, but a beautiful woman with brains and force of personality. The first two might get her a hearing where others would not, but the second two are what keep Free Folk listening.

“The good woman at the brazier,” Mance Rayder went on, “is Dalla.” The pregnant woman smiled shyly. “Treat her like you would any queen, she is carrying my child.” He turned to the last two. “This beauty is her sister Val. Young Jarl beside her is her latest pet.”

- Jon I, ASoS

Mance here explicitly flags that between Val and Jarl, Val’s in charge. Later, when Jon sends her to speak with Tormund (who she knows), we see her courage.

“The horse may be half-blind, but I am not,” said Val. “I know where I must go.”

“My lady, you do not have to do this. The risk—”

“—is mine, Lord Snow. And I am no southron lady but a woman of the free folk. I know the forest better than all your black-cloaked rangers. It holds no ghosts for me.”

- Jon VIII, ADWD

Later, we see her converse with Selyse Baratheon.

“Free folk do not kneel,” Val told her.

“Then they must be knelt,” the queen declared.

“Do that, Your Grace, and we will rise again at the first chance,” Val promised. “Rise with blades in hand.”

- Jon XI, ADWD

Even accounting for cultural differences, that’s certainly some backtalk to a queen.

But even then, Jon points out repeatedly, both to Stannis and his people and to the readers, that Val’s got no formal position with the Free Folk; the only influence she has with them is what she makes for herself.

summary: Hi, I’ve been reading your Dany and Jon asks and I am really curious why you think the political!jon/ucl theory goes against the...
question: Hi, I’ve been reading your Dany and Jon asks and I am really curious why you think the political!jon/ucl theory goes against the themes of the books? Thanks!
answer:
“It was the cold,” Gared said with iron certainty. “I saw men freeze last winter, and the one before, when I was half a boy. Everyone talks about snows forty foot deep, and how the ice wind comes howling out of the north, but the real enemy is the cold.”

- Prologue, AGoT

The prologue’s there to frame the conflict of the entire series, and it’s outright stated that the cold is the enemy. (And at the end of the book, Dany proclaims that the fire is hers. Bookends.) The ultimate antagonist in this series is an inhuman, anti-human force against which all humanity should unite. 

The idea that people should work together to face threats greater than themselves recurs across the series. Whether it’s Ned telling Arya that she and Sansa will need each other, Catelyn imploring the Baratheon brothers to work together, or Jon and Stannis making common cause at the Wall itself, the idea’s there. The White Walkers are a problem bigger than anyone, and people should work together. The idea that at the business end of the series one of the protagonists will callously manipulate another protagonist into helping sort out the final showdown is just bizarre to me. Especially when the other option is one protagonist convincing another protagonist to lend a hand and a few dragons, nothing but good faith between them. Even the show has started to bear in this direction from time to time.

I think this theory is also pretty OOC for even the show versions of Jon and Dany. The show’s got its issues with showing us one thing and telling us another, but that theory pretty well denies that Dany could ever want to save the world because the world’s worth saving, and ignores Jon’s distress over deceiving Ygritte.

Given the options between “offscreen, Jon decided to give up on a good faith alliance with Daenerys and instead seduce her into offering her assistance,” and “the Jon/Dany romance writing did not come off altogether as convincing as intended,” I know which I find more plausible.

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: I definitely think Jon Snow will ride Viserion
body:
I definitely think Jon Snow will ride Viserion

  • White like Ghost
  • Viserion is the same color scheme as the Kingsgaurd, and as I like the idea of Jon becoming Lord Commander of the Kingsguard
  • As of the show, Jon is a Man of Ice, resurrected of Fire; Viserion is a Creature of Fire brought back by Ice
  • The name Viserion is from Viserys, which may function as a male version of Visenya; which would’ve been Jon’s name as Rhaegar and Lyanna were expecting a girl to be named Visenya

tags: im tired of them ruining this story
these characters are being butchered on screen
summary: People who say that jon is a “Targaryen” or even a “stark” are completely ignoring his story arc. The whole point is that Jon...
body: People who say that jon is a “Targaryen” or even a “stark” are completely ignoring his story arc. The whole point is that Jon realizes that he doesn’t need a family name to be worthy. It’s his actions that make him who he is not his parentage. It’s actually a really compelling narrative that is being completely overlooked in the show (because for some reason they love a good nasty incest plot) and also by people in the fandom. By ignoring this his character is being reduced significantly into just another pawn in the game of thrones. The point of Jon, dany, and Tyrion are that they don’t fit into this world as they’re “supposed to.” It’s just really frustrating that people are turning Jon, who is actually a very interesting and relatable character, into someone so dull and redundant. Jon as a character deserves much more than that. He is not jon stark or Jon Targaryen (or god forbid aegon) he is Jon Snow.

Jon as a character deserves much more than that. He is not jon stark or Jon Targaryen (or god forbid aegon) he is Jon Snow.

The whole point is that Jon realizes that he doesn’t need a family name to be worthy. It’s his actions that make him who he is not his parentage. It’s actually a really compelling narrative that is being completely overlooked in the show (because for some reason they love a good nasty incest plot) and also by people in the fandom. By ignoring this his character is being reduced significantly into just another pawn in the game of thrones. The point of Jon, dany, and Tyrion are that they don’t fit into this world as they’re “supposed to.” It’s just really frustrating that people are turning Jon, who is actually a very interesting and relatable character, into someone so dull and redundant. Jon as a character deserves much more than that. He is not jon stark or Jon Targaryen (or god forbid aegon) he is Jon Snow.

It’s his actions that make him who he is not his parentage. It’s actually a really compelling narrative that is being completely overlooked in the show (because for some reason they love a good nasty incest plot) and also by people in the fandom. By ignoring this his character is being reduced significantly into just another pawn in the game of thrones. The point of Jon, dany, and Tyrion are that they don’t fit into this world as they’re “supposed to.” It’s just really frustrating that people are turning Jon, who is actually a very interesting and relatable character, into someone so dull and redundant. Jon as a character deserves much more than that. He is not jon stark or Jon Targaryen (or god forbid aegon) he is Jon Snow.

blog.name: qinaliel
blog.title: I fumble with words and twirl unnecessarily.
blog.description: Welcome to the randomness: my photography, ASoIaF/Game of Thrones, House Stark, The Princess Bride, Kit Harington, Sophie Turner, the CHRISes, Garrett Hedlund, and anything that tickles my fancy. All photos are mine ©, unless stated otherwise (i.e. an edit) or reblogged because of the feels.

summary: Just looked at my email and saw a bunch of lovely comments from you - thanks so much! made my day!
question: Just looked at my email and saw a bunch of lovely comments from you - thanks so much! made my day!
answer:
I am STILL up thinking about this fic! You’ve gutted me! I’m afraid to look at the timestamps from my first comment to my last comment that shows how obsessed I was to finish this in one sitting. I most definitely stand by my last comment, especially about how you brought to life the fan speculations on Bran’s POV in A Game Of Thrones.

You’re welcome and TRULY THANK YOU for writing this!

If anyone seeing this loves a well-written, on point characterization, angst with a side of crime drama, modern AU then please click this link and get lost (I say affectionately!).
